climbs.name: Sugar Twist
climbs.fa: John Knight, Tim Morgan, Iain McDonald, Richard Fernandez

content.description: Interesting, twisting chimney with a series of creative chimney and stemming moves. If you like chimneys, you will enjoy this climb. You'll find yourself twisting between the left and right walls to figure out the best way to move up. Depending on your chimney comfort level it may feel 5.7 or 5.9. Give it a go and let me know what you think. The crux is probably the first 10' off the ground after clipping the first bolt. Although the rating is moderate, this lead is probably best for a competent 5.9 leader.
content.protection: Five bolts plus a #2 cam near the top. You can supplement with smaller gear if needed.
content.location: See main page description to get to base of Little Sugarloaf.

content.description: Bolted face climb that will keep you paying attention. There is a tricky clip between bolts 3 and 4 that could lead to a ledge fall if you miss the clip. This is probably suitable for competent 5.9 leaders. If you figure out the sequence, it may feel more like 5.8. Can be set up as a top rope from the top of Little Sugarloaf. After climbing Sugar Cookie, check out the top rope about 30' to the right. The anchors can be carefully accessed from the top of Little Sugarloaf.
content.protection: Just 5 bolts. Anchors are about 25' above the last bolt after doing a bit of 4th Class climbing.
content.location: See main Little Sugarloaf page for directions. The climb starts around the corner to the right of Sugar Twist on the northeast face.

climbs.name: Sugar Buns
climbs.fa: John Knight, Tim Morgan, Richard Fernandez

content.description: Starts out with some easy steps then gets progressively steeper. Finishes on a 15' long hand crack.
content.protection: Bolts plus small to medium gear for the upper crack. You might want to bring a 0.1 to #2 Camalot for the crack section.
content.location: See main page for directions to crag. Can be set up as a TR if you rap down to the anchors from the top of Little Sugarloaf.

content.description: Easy, short approach with several sport climbs that are supplemented with a bit of trad protection. East facing and northeast facing climbs. Currently, there are 3 lead climbs and one top rope. There is potential for additional climbs on this feature.
